content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is a primary duty of government. Banning specific types of firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons to harm innocent citizens. The most effective way to ensure public safety from gun-related crimes is to maintain law and order. To protect public safety from gun-related crimes, the most effective approach is to arrest, convict, and incarcerate violent criminals to prevent them from quickly returning to the streets. Banning specific types of firearms does not deter criminals from acquiring weapons to harm innocent citizens. SEC. 3. ARMED VIOLENT CRIMINAL APPREHENSION DIRECTIVE. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Each US attorney must designate a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. Each US attorney must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension task force to develop strategies for removing armed violent criminals from the streets, considering the importance of severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, and available resources. The US attorney must consider the importance of severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, resources available to law enforcement agencies, nature of violent crime, and limited Federal involvement in prosecuting crimes. The Attorney General requires each US attorney to report monthly on the number of defendants charged with violating specific sections of title 18. The Attorney General mandates monthly reports from US attorneys on defendants charged with violating specific sections of title 18, United States Code. Additionally, semi-annual compilations of this information are submitted to Congress. The Attorney General must also submit semi-annual compilations of this information to Congress, along with a report on waivers granted under subsection (b) for United States attorneys. United States attorneys can request the Attorney General to waive the requirements of subsection (a) for them. The Department of Justice receives information on waivers granted under subsection (b) for US attorneys. A US attorney can request the Attorney General to waive the requirements of subsection (a) for them. The Attorney General may grant the waiver based on established guidelines. The Attorney General may waive the requirements of subsection (a) for a US attorney upon request, based on established guidelines considering the number of assistant United States attorneys and the level of violent crime in the district. The term "armed violent criminal" refers to a person accused of violent crimes. The Attorney General can waive requirements for a US attorney based on the number of assistant United States attorneys and the level of violent crime in the district. An "armed violent criminal" is someone accused of violating specific sections of the United States Code. This section will expire after five years from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF THE PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by removing subsections (v) and (w) and the appendix. Section 921(a) is amended by removing paragraph (30). Section 921(a)(31)(A) is amended by removing certain phrases. Section 923(i) is amended by removing the last 2 sentences. Section 924(a)(1)(B) is amended by removing references to subsections (r), (v), or (w). Section 110104 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is repealed, while various sections of title 18, United States Code, are amended by removing subsections (v) and (w), certain phrases, and references to subsections (r), (v), or (w). Section 923(i) is also amended by striking the last 2 sentences. SEC. 5. Mandatory prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment specifies enhanced punishments for using a deadly weapon in such crimes, including additional imprisonment for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm with intent to injure another person. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Enhanced punishments include additional imprisonment for brandishing or discharging a firearm with intent to injure, with specific sentencing guidelines based on the type of firearm used. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates additional imprisonment for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentence is increased based on the type of firearm used, with specific sentencing guidelines for different types of firearms. The amendment to Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates additional imprisonment for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The sentence is increased based on the type of firearm used, with specific sentencing guidelines for different types of firearms. For example, possession of a machinegun or destructive device, or a firearm equipped with a silencer or muffler, results in an additional 30 years of imprisonment. In the case of a second or subsequent conviction, the individual faces a minimum of 20 years in prison if a firearm was possessed during the crime. If a person brandishes a firearm during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they will be sentenced to at least 25 years in prison. If the person discharges a firearm with the intent to injure another person during such a crime, they will face a minimum of 30 years in prison. If a person discharges a firearm with the intent to injure during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they will face a minimum of 30 years in prison. If a person uses a firearm in a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they will face a minimum of 30 years in prison. Additionally, if the firearm is a machinegun, destructive device, or equipped with a silencer or muffler, the person will be sentenced to life imprisonment. The court cannot impose probation or concurrent sentences for this offense. The court cannot impose probation or concurrent sentences for a person convicted of using a firearm in a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The individual sentenced under this provision will not be released for any reason during their imprisonment term.
